newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Asia Naphtha/Mogas - Supplies bear down on naphtha.
newsitem.headline: Asia Naphtha/Mogas - Supplies bear down on naphtha.

text.p: Ample supplies of naphtha and high stocks depressed prices while gasoline remained steady in a balanced market, traders said on Friday.
Naphtha September swaps fell by 30 cents per barrel to $21.15/$21.20.
"The Japanese have increased their domestic production of naphtha and have no need to import," said a Japanese trader. "In fact some are trying to defer their term liftings from the Middle East."
Thai buying which caused a bull-run in July was also absent from the market as the mercury removing unit at Aromatic Thailand's plant came back onstream on August 12, a source said.
The company needs to import around one cargo per month but had already covered its September requirements.

Only Taiwan's state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp (CPC) was an active buyer, seeking 30,000 tonnes of full range naphtha for delivery between October 1-31 in a tender which closes August 20 and is valid for two days.
CPC's last full range naphtha tender, for September 1-10 delivery was awarded to South Korean refiner Yukong Ltd at $203 per tonne on a cost-and-freight (c-and-f) basis, industry sources said.
In the absence of buyers, Singapore refiners were not actively offering September cargoes, although some lifting schedules would only be confirmed next week.
Traders assessed premiums at flat to a "small premium' after one major sold a full cargo earlier this month at par to Singapore spot quotes.
"If you can get flat, you are lucky," said one U.S. major.
Indonesia was adding to the already oversupplied market with a very prompt August 18-22 lifting 200,000-barrel full range cargo heard being offered from Dumai.
Gasoline in comparison, looked healthier after Taiwan's tender this week removed 750,000 barrels out of September.
A European major sold 50,000-barrels of unleaded 97-octane gasoline lifting Septmber 1-5 to a Dutch trader at $24.55 per barrel fob Singapore.
"The levels are steady and look okay because naphtha is coming down and the spread is widening," a trader said.
The spread between gasoline and naphtha, the reforming margin has been under pressure with a surplus of gasoline since last year, forcing cuts in reformer output.
The cuts have in turn tightened supplies of the high octane creating a two-tiered market between high and low octane material.
Traders assessed the spread between naphtha and the 97-octane at $3.70, while it was only $2.20 lower than the 95-octane.
China was offering the 92 and 97-octane material while India cancelled its buy tender for 87.15 octane.
(Prices are in dollars per barrel)
MTH FOB SIN BUY/SELL PREV BUY/SELL
SEP NAPHTHA SWAPS 21.15/21.20 21.40/21.55
OCT NAPHTHA SWAPS 21.10/21.20 21.40/21.55
SEP GASOLINE SWAPS - - -/- - - - - -/- - -
